titlStmt.titl: Assessing Ventilatory Control in Infants at High Risk of Sleep Disordered Breathing: A Study of Infants with Cleft Lip and/or Palate
Assessing Ventilatory Control in Infants at High Risk of Sleep Disordered Breathing: A Study of Infants with Cleft Lip and/or Palate

prodStmt.software: Sandman Digital 32+ Amplifier and Elite Sleep Diagnostic Software

useStmt.restrctn: Author determines access on a case-by-case basis
useStmt.conditions: Access is limited to the research team
Access is permitted for external researchers, with limitations

Access to deidentified data may be permitted for external researchers, with limitations. Only researchers with REB-approved projects may be permitted access to the deidentified data. The data producer determines access on a case-by-case basis. Contact the data producer directly to discuss terms and conditions of access.

setAvail.accsPlac: Data is stored on PIs hard drive.
setAvail.avlStatus: Restricted: Data may be available but requires the user to request permission before access can be granted.

stdyInfo.abstract: The objective of this study was to determine the impact of sleep disordered breathing (SDB) in early infancy on ventilatory response in infants. We recruited consecutive infants with cleft lip and/or palate (CL/P) to undergo ventilatory response testing using exposure to a hypoxic (15% O(2) ) gas mixture during sleep. This population is at high risk of SDB because of smaller airway caliber and abnormal palatal muscle attachments predisposing them to airway obstruction of ranging severity from birth.

sumDscr.geogCover: New South Wales, Westmead, The Children's Hospital at Westmead
sumDscr.universe: Newborn infants with cleft lip and/or palate (CL/P).

dataColl.sampProc: The target subject number was 20. It was chosen based on the number of subjects in previous studies in this area, as the absence of an estimated effect size precluded sample size calculations. The actual sample size was 22. The sample was chosen through consecutive screening and enrollment; all families with infants born with (CL/P) at the Children's Hospital at Westmead during the time of the study were approached to participate
dataColl.frequenc: Data was collected at one time point.
dataColl.actMin: Standardized data collection forms were used. In the event of missing data, the PI followed up with families.
dataColl.ConOps: There were standard operating procedures (SOPs) in place for the sleep study and ventilatory control measures.
dataColl.cleanOps: Physiological data was reviewed for outliers. Individual breaths with tidal volume (VT), respiratory rate (RR) or minute ventilation (VE) that lay outside the 95% confidence interval for all infants were removed as outliers; 99.7% of all measured breaths were included in the final analyses.

source.dataSrc: American Academy of Sleep Medicine respiratory rules for children; Hypoxia Protocol, described in Parslow PM, Harding R, Cranage SM, Adamson TM, Horne RS. Ventilatory responses preceding hypoxia-induced arousal in infants: effects of sleep-state. Respir Physiol Neurobiol 2003; 136: 235- 247.

othrStdyMat.relPubl: MacLean, JE, Tan, S, Fitzgerald, DA and Waters, KA (2013), Assessing ventilatory control in infants at high risk of sleep disordered breathing: A study of infants with cleft lip and/or palate. Pediatric Pulmonology, 48: 265-273.
othrStdyMat.othRefs: MacLean JE, Fitzgerald DA, Hayward P, Waters KA. Cleft lip and/or palate and breathing during sleep. Sleep Medicine Reviews 2009; 13: 345-354 MacLean JE, Fitzsimons D, Fitzgerald DA, Waters KA. The spectrum of sleep-disordered breathing symptoms and respiratory events in infants with cleft lip and/or palate. Archives of Disease in Childhood 2012; 97: 1058-63 Smith CB, Walker K, Badawi N, Waters KA, MacLean JE. Impact of sleep and breathing in infancy on outcomes at 3 years of age for children with cleft lip and/or palate. Sleep. 2014; 37: 919-25
